p: The change in maximum CO 2 is not as large as the change in electricity production because additional capacity in mid-century (necessary to meet increased demand) is generated by natural gas power plants based on the US EIAâ€™s Annual Energy Outlook, which emit less carbon than the current mix of generation sources [ 36]. We find that electricity production and emissions in the present-day exhibit a more uniform distribution than does temperature ( Fig 2). This difference is due to the changing sensitivity of electricity generation as a function of temperature, with responsiveness increasing at higher temperatures and decreasing at cooler temperatures, when building cooling is less important. The distribution becomes less uniform in the mid-century climate as temperature dependence plays a greater role compared to other end uses of electricity.
